chapter.htmlHeader: What else might it be?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Other causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia include:
    • Haemolysis
      • Auto-immune haemolytic anaemias.
      • Sickle cell anaemia.
      • Thalassaemia.
      • Hereditary spherocytosis.
      • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.
      • Prosthetic heart valves.
      • Reabsorption of a large haematoma (excessive haemoglobin breakdown increases bilirubin production).
    • Genetic causes.
      • Crigler–Najjar syndrome type I  a rare, recessively inherited condition in which there is no bilirubin conjugation in the liver, resulting in severe progressive jaundice in neonates in the first few days of life. If left untreated, it leads to bilirubin encephalopathy (kernicterus). Bilirubin levels reach 350–950 micromol/L and life expectancy is usually less than 1 year.
      • Crigler–Najjar syndrome type II —  an inherited condition that is thought to be due to a combination of a Gilbert's syndrome defect and a Crigler–Najjar type I defect, in which conjugating enzyme activity is less than 10%. It is less severe than type I and brain damage does not occur. Bilirubin levels are less than 350 micromol/L.
    • Drugs
      • Methyldopa and sulfasalazine can cause haemolysis.
      • Rifampicin can impair hepatic bilirubin clearance.
    • Physiological neonatal jaundice.
      • Harmless unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, often with mild clinical jaundice, occurs in all full term newborn infants. The bilirubin concentration increases to a maximum 2–5 days after birth and rarely exceeds 90 micromol/L. It is more severe in preterm babies owing to the combination of immaturity of enzymes and added bilirubin load from rapid haemolysis of surplus fetal red blood cells in the neonatal period. Breastfeeding slightly increases serum bilirubin levels.
  • Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia include:
    • Gallstones.
    • Fatty liver disease.
    • Infection:
      • Viral hepatitis. (For further information see the CKS topics on Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C.
      • Cytomegalovirus.
      • Epstein-Barr virus.
    • Drugs:
      • Paracetamol poisoning — a subset of people with Gilbert's syndrome may be more susceptible to liver damage after an overdose.
      • Alcoholic hepatitis.
      • Erythromycin.
      • Oestrogens.
      • Corticosteroids (For further information see the CKS topics on Corticosteroids - inhaled, Corticosteroids - oral, and Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes).
      • Chlorpromazine.
      • Halothane toxicity.
    • Metabolic:
      • Ischaemic hepatitis.
      • Wilson's disease.
      • Haemochromatosis.
      • Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency.
    • Autoimmune:
      • Primary biliary cirrhosis.
      • Primary sclerosing cholangitis.
      • Autoimmune hepatitis.
    • Malignancy and infiltrative:
      • Cholangiocarcinoma.
      • Extrinsic compression from other malignancy.
      • Tuberculosis.
      • Lymphoma.
      • Amyloidosis.
      • Sarcoidosis.
      • Non-metastatic renal carcinoma.
      • Metastatic carcinoma.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The information on the differential diagnosis of unconjugated and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is based on expert opinion in the Oxford textbook of medicine [Thompson, 2010], expert opinion in review articles [Esteban and Perez-Mateo, 1999; Hirschfield and Alexander, 2006; Claridge, 2011; Sticova and Jirsa, 2013] and the expert opinion of a previous external reviewer of this CKS topic.
